report_title: Industry Report on Private Schools in the United States
executive_summary: The private primary and secondary education industry's revenue heavily depends on student enrollment, which has been challenged by falling birth rates and rising funding for public schools. However, a surge in revenue during the COVID-19 pandemic offset other losses. Tuition has climbed as higher-cost private schools gained dominance, but not enough to generate positive long-term revenue growth. The industry owes its net revenue growth since 2019 to the pandemic making private schools more attractive. Revenue climbed at a 1.9% CAGR to reach $98.9 billion over the past five years, despite sinking 1.7% in 2024.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Revenue is up amid a single-year spike and a long-term decline
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Private school enrollment growth drifted into negative territory through the early period, but this downturn was offset by solid growth at the height of COVID-19. Public schools were more heavily restricted through the pandemic, and parents sought private schools to give their children a smaller environment with more flexibility.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: The Youth Population is Shrinking in the Long-Term, Threatening Enrollment
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: As students left public schools and came to private schools, enrollment spiked. Tuition continued to rise as enrollment climbed, boosting revenue. The rebound in enrollment was short-lived, though, and has since returned to its previous decline as birth rates sink and inflation strains on household budgets.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Private Secular High Schools Are Outperforming Other Institutions
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Private high schools are outperforming private elementary schools. These schools are fewer in number, more selective and more expensive. This significantly reduces revenue volatility. Elementary schools are more accessible, so households easily switch away from private schools following economic shocks.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Larger Schools Will Fare Better Through the Next Period
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Long-run demographic shifts, especially declining birth rates, will continue to slash private schools' enrollment. High-cost, selective private secondary schools will receive a steady flow of students and outperform elementary schools.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Charter School Competition Will Hamper Elementary Private Schools
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Competition for lackluster funding for public schools is expected to worsen the quality of public school education. Households fed up with public school systems can seek alternatives, like private schooling. The growing market share of high-cost schools will price many households out of the market, though, limiting enrollment growth for the industry.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Tuition Hikes Will Drive Revenue Growth
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Tuition for private schooling is on the rise as higher-cost schools become more dominant in the market. Still, high-income households are less price-sensitive and will continue enrolling in the nation's top private schools despite rising costs.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: A Strong Economic Environment Will Mitigate Enrollment Declines
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Despite declining birth rates, a prolonged economic expansion in the coming years has the potential to stem the tide of shrinking private school enrollment. As economic conditions improve, incomes swell and consumers enjoy expanded discretionary budgets, they may consider spending money on a private education rather than sending their children to public school.

industry_definition: The Private Schools industry comprises primary (grades K-6) and secondary (grades 7-12) educational institutions that are predominantly funded through tuition fees and other private sources. While these schools may receive indirect government funding through special programs, such sources of revenue are not their primary means of funding.

positive_impact_factors: high - steady barriers to entry level

threats: Low Performance Drivers: Number of K-12 students

key_trends: Reputation sets some private schools apart. While tuition plays a major role on the lower end of the cost spectrum, high-earning parents are much more sensitive to a private school's credentials and reputation.
Academics and athletics separate private schools. Parents view private school classes and extracurriculars as springboards to admission at top colleges.
Declining birth rates are posing a long-term threat to the industry. Private schools are having a hard time replacing their graduating students as consumers choose to have fewer or no children.

Households have struggled to pay tuition amid inflation. Disposable income has taken a downturn as grocery trips have become more expensive, bringing strong pandemic-era growth in enrollment to a screeching halt.

Private schools range significantly in size. Some schools are preparatory institutions rivaling colleges, while others are tiny academies with three student classes. This prevents any major schools from taking over market share.
New private schools need to become accredited. In order to begin instructing students, entrants need to prove to their state's board that their education is equivalent to that of a public school.
Charter schools are siphoning away enrollment. Parents looking for an alternative to public schools are often opting for more affordable charter schools, especially amid inflation.
Private schools differentiate themselves by investing in advertisements and events. Schools must make themselves known to parents in the area in order to attract new students.
Wage costs are consistently high. Maintaining a staff of highly skilled teachers is critical to success, but these employees don't come cheap.

Some private institutions serve as feeder schools. States with prestigious Ivy League colleges foster an environment where parents are likely to choose a private school that will up their child's chances of landing a spot at a major university.
High-income areas attract private school students. Private schools are more expensive than public alternatives, so locating near bodies of well-off parents is key to success.

Secular schools are becoming more popular. Levels of religiosity are dropping among US consumers, and high-earning parents are becoming more likely to choose a nonreligious private school over one affiliated with a church.

Small catholic schools are struggling to compete with large institutions. Low-cost schools are losing enrollment, but the top Catholic private schools have secured loyal client bases that have protected them from declines and given them more dominance in the market.

Elementary schools are having trouble filling classrooms. While high schools face a delayed impact from declining birth rates, a falling youth population is making replacing aging students more difficult.

market_segmentation.segment_description: Enrollment in private elementary schools has fluctuated through the current period. The COVID-19 pandemic pushed younger students out of public schools and into private schools in 2020 as parents anxiously awaiting public school reopening made the switch in droves. Many of these students have remained in private schools even as public schools reopened.

Middle and high schools are outperforming their younger counterparts. Charging higher tuition brings in more revenue per school, regardless of lower total enrollment. High schools' share of total private school enrollment has made leaps and bounds through the current period.

Middle and high schools are outperforming their younger counterparts. Charging higher tuition brings in more revenue per school, regardless of lower total enrollment. High schools' share of total private school enrollment has made leaps and bounds through the current period.

products_and_services.product_description: Catholic schools serve Catholic and non-Catholic students. Catholic schools' low cost has preserved enrollment in the past five years in spite of a long-term trend of declining Catholicism among US parents. These low tuition rates have reduced this segment's contribution to industry revenue.

products_and_services.product_or_service: Secular Schools Are Becoming More Popular
products_and_services.product_description: Secular schools don't have a religious orientation. Secular schools boast the lowest share of private school enrollment but command the largest share of industry revenue. Tuition rates well above those of religious schools give secular schools high market share concentration.

Schools in this segment have a religious orientation but are not directly affiliated with the Roman Catholic Church. Baptist, Lutheran, Jewish, Episcopal, Calvinist, Non-Denominational Christian and other religious schools are included in this segment.

demand_determinants.determinant_title: Fewer Parents Are Choosing Catholic Schools for Their Kids
demand_determinants.determinant_description: Catholic schools serve Catholic and non-Catholic students. Catholic schools' low cost has preserved enrollment in the past five years in spite of a long-term trend of declining Catholicism among US parents.
The number of school-aged children encompasses the potential market of private schools. Growth in the student population drives enrollment at private schools.

business_locations.location_description: The Southeast has many large cities, particularly in Florida. Wealthy areas throughout Florida and the Carolinas are home to most of the region's private schools.
High population density and income spur demand for private schools.
Western states like California house a large and dense population, much of which is made up of households bringing in over $100,000 per year.
Some of the oldest private schools in the country are in New England, and the region's rich history keeps private schools a prominent feature of its education system.

regulations_points.regulation_description: Private schools must be registered and approved by state officials.
Private schools are subject to a variety of government regulations and requirements.
Several states have passed school voucher or tuition tax credit programs.

basis_points.basis_title: Reputation sets some private schools apart
basis_points.basis_description: While tuition plays a major role on the lower end of the cost spectrum, high-earning parents are much more sensitive to a private school's credentials and reputation.

basis_points.basis_title: Academics and athletics separate private schools
basis_points.basis_description: Parents view private school classes and extracurriculars as springboards to admission at top colleges.

concentration_points.concentration_title: DECLINING BIRTH RATES ARE PROPPING UP HIGH SCHOOLS
concentration_points.concentration_description: Lower birth rates are leading to a shrinking youth population, which shifts market share to high schools in the short run.

concentration_points.concentration_title: Secular Schools Are Gaining Ground Over Religious Institutions
concentration_points.concentration_description: Steadily declining rates of religiosity among US consumers.

cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Private schools need to attract qualified teachers.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Schools Invest in Technology and Equipment
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Private schools are making efforts to provide modern educational tools.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Advertisements and Promotional Events Bring in New Students
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Marketing expenses are essential for private schools.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Financial Aid Supports Private School Enrollment
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Many schools provide financial aid to enroll students.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_title: Novel Teaching Methods First Appear in Private Schools

volatility_points.volatility_description: Enrollment in private schools increased due to COVID-19.

volatility_points.volatility_title: A shrinking potential market guides the long-term downward trend
volatility_points.volatility_description: A shrinking youth population is weighing on enrollment.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: Novel Teaching Methods First Appear in Private Schools
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Skilled private school teachers bring forth novel and creative teaching methods.

FAQs.question: Has demand for your institution shifted at all as religious preferences have changed?
FAQs.answer: Enrollment in Catholic schools has been on the decline in recent years due to changing religiosity rates.

FAQs.question: Have you changed your willingness to pay for tuition?
FAQs.answer: Schools are beginning to incorporate new technologies to give students and teachers more flexibility.
